thread_structure: Most people have no idea what goes into making 10,000 croissants before sunrise. Here's what our overnight shift looks like:
2 AM: Mixers start running. 500 lbs of flour, precise water temp (we're talking ±2°F), and the magic begins.
3 AM: First lamination pass. Each batch gets folded 6 times. This creates those flaky layers you love.
4 AM: Shaping begins. Our team can shape 200 croissants per hour (after years of practice).
5 AM: Proofing. Temperature and humidity controlled to the degree. This is where science meets art.
6 AM: Baking starts. Ovens at 375°F. The smell that fills the bakery at this moment is indescribable.
7 AM: First batch delivered to cafes across the city while they're still warm.
The next time you bite into a fresh croissant, remember: it took 5 hours and a team of skilled bakers to create that moment.

thread_structure: I once ruined 800 dinner rolls 30 minutes before a wedding. Here's what I learned about crisis management in a commercial bakery:
The mistake: Salt and sugar containers got swapped during overnight shift. Didn't catch it until the first batch came out.
The panic: Wedding started in 3 hours. Venue was 45 minutes away. No time to start from scratch.
The solution: Called every bakery within 20 miles. Found one with capacity. Split our team - half remade rolls, half coordinated logistics.
The coordination: Our driver picked up 400 rolls from partner bakery. We finished 400 more. Both batches arrived on time.
The lesson: Build relationships with other bakeries. Your 'competitors' might save you one day. We've returned the favor twice since.
Also: Label everything. Double-check everything. Have a crisis protocol.
That wedding couple never knew anything went wrong. That's the job.

Years 13+: You're an artist. You innovate. You mentor. You're irreplaceable.
Maria makes $72K/year + profit sharing + health insurance. Some think that's high for a baker.
I think it's a bargain for someone who ensures 10,000 perfect products leave our bakery every week.
Invest in your people. Pay them well. They'll invest in your business.

twitter_content_templates.hook_tweet: 5 things commercial bakeries do that home bakers should steal:
thread_structure: 5 things commercial bakeries do that home bakers should steal:
1. Weigh everything. Cups are inconsistent. Grams are exact. A $15 scale will transform your baking.
2. Room temp ingredients. Butter, eggs, milk - all should be 65-70°F. Cold ingredients = uneven mixing.
3. Lower your oven temp by 25°F. Home ovens run hot and have hot spots. Lower temp + longer time = better results.
4. Use the windowpane test for dough. Stretch a small piece - if it forms a thin, translucent membrane without tearing, gluten is developed.
5. Cool completely before cutting. Bread continues cooking internally. Cut too soon = gummy texture.
Bonus: Invest in good parchment paper. Cheap stuff burns. Quality parchment is reusable and makes cleanup easy.
